question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find the remainder when $24^{50} - 15^{50}$ is divided by 13.
inference:
By Fermat's Little Theorem, $a^{12} \equiv 1 \pmod{13}$ for any integer $a$ not divisible by 13.
$24 \equiv 11 \pmod{13}$. Then
$24^{50} \equiv 11^{50} \pmod{13}$.
$11^2 = 121 \equiv 121-9\times13 = 121 - 117 = 4 \pmod{13}$.
$11^4 \equiv 4^2 \equiv 16 \equiv 3 \pmod{13}$.
$11^8 \equiv 3^2 \equiv 9 \pmod{13}$.
$11^{10} \equiv 11^8 \times 11^2 \equiv 9 \times 4 \equiv 36 \equiv 10 \pmod{13}$.
$11^{50} = 11^{10 \times 5} = (11^{10})^5 \equiv 10^5 \pmod{13}$.
$10^2 \equiv 100 \equiv 100 - 7 \times 13 = 100-91 = 9 \pmod{13}$.
$10^4 \equiv 9^2 \equiv 81 \equiv 81-6\times13 = 81-78 = 3 \pmod{13}$.
$10^5 \equiv 10^4 \times 10^1 \equiv 3 \times 10 \equiv 30 \equiv 4 \pmod{13}$.
$11^{50} \equiv 4 \pmod{13}$.
$15 \equiv 2 \pmod{13}$. Then
$15^{50} \equiv 2^{50} \pmod{13}$.
$2^2 = 4 \pmod{13}$.
$2^4 = 16 \equiv 3 \pmod{13}$.
$2^8 \equiv 3^2 \equiv 9 \pmod{13}$.
$2^{10} \equiv 2^8 \times 2^2 \equiv 9 \times 4 \equiv 36 \equiv 10 \pmod{13}$.
$2^{20} = (2^{10})^2 \equiv 10^2 \equiv 9 \pmod{13}$.
$2^{40} = (2^{20})^2 \equiv 9^2 \equiv 81 \equiv 3 \pmod{13}$.
$2^{50} = 2^{40} \times 2^{10} \equiv 3 \times 10 \equiv 30 \equiv 4 \pmod{13}$.
$24^{50} - 15^{50} \equiv 11^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv 4-4 \equiv 0 \pmod{13}$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{0}$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: We note that $24 \equiv -2 \pmod{13}$ and $15 \equiv 2 \pmod{13}$.  We cleverly use these congruences to set up values that vanish in the arithmetic: $$ 24^{50} - 15^{50} \equiv (-2)^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv 2^{50} - 2^{50} \equiv \boxed{0} \pmod{13}. $$
